Hi @jkosh44 ; I see you also created #682. Thank you for that. Please be aware that if you want a pull request to reference an issue, you can use the syntax `#681` instead of `Issue 681`. GitHub will automatically link if you use the former syntax, but it doesn't link if you use the latter.

Also, keep in mind that there is no reason to create an issue, and then immediately create a pull request. On GitHub, pull requests *are* issues, so that is redundant. Sometimes we create an issue to track future work, or one person creates an issue and then another person creates a pull request. But if you're creating both, only minutes apart, it's redundant.

Hi @byungwok . This does not appear to be an Accumulo issue. It may be related to Cloudera CDH or Geowave, but this is not the right forum to get support for either of those (I suspect both of those have their own community forums for support, but I don't know what they are). Also, please note that Accumulo 1.7.x is not an actively maintained version of Accumulo. You should probably upgrade to the latest, 1.9.2, unless you are receiving support for the earlier version from your vendor.

From the exception, it looks like either 1) the jar file is corrupt, 2) you don't have the appropriate unzip library installed on your system to unpack the jar, or 3) the file system permissions to do not permit your accumulo process to read the jar. It's also possible that the issue was fixed in commons-vfs2-2.1, which I know has some bug fixes in it, and you may be able to put on your class path in place of commons-vfs2-2.0, but I can't be certain it will fix this specific issue.

Hopefully the above suggestions will help. However, I'm closing this issue, since it does not appear to be a problem with Accumulo.
@dlmarion Could you take a look at this as well?

The error message is wrong. The deprecated property is `tserver.readahead.concurrent.max` which was set in my configuration.  The error message needs to be fixed and this error should only be printed once.
This also fixes https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ACCUMULO-3949
@adamjshook  - interesting. just so I understand the use-case here. All tservers are involved in defined groups such that the default group is empty?

@dlmarion That'd either be the case, or the tablet servers in the default pool are unavailable.  We use the regex balancer to isolate a few larger tables and every other table (including the `accumulo.*` system tables) are in the default pool.  If all tservers in the default pool were to go down, then clients won't be able to access these tables (and in turn the system tables, which would cripple everything as you'd expect).  This ensures that they'll be assigned to some other (random) pool.
This seems pretty useful for info level.  Is there another place where this gets logged as well?  Is this duplicate information?

@adamjshook  IIRC you can have regex's that overlap, for example you could spread table1 over rack1, table2 over rack2, and table3 over racks 1 and 2. I'm still looking at this PR, but I wonder if it would be simpler to just add all tservers to the default pool if it ends up being empty.

@adamjshook - for example, [at](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/c67808da94c291d8841fb50ebea9c47fe51f570c/server/base/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/server/master/balancer/HostRegexTableLoadBalancer.java#L146), check to see if the DEFAULT_POOL is empty, if so, add all of the current tservers to it.

Looked over code and test. Code looks correct given approach taken, but I wonder if there is a hidden danger there. For example you may have a small table distributed over just a handful of tablet servers (say for example you pin the accumulo.metadata table to a handful of nodes). Given the current approach its probable that you could balance an entire table within that small group of servers.

@dlmarion I see, so rather than selecting a random pool, we'd be better off just assigning all tablet servers into the default pool.  I like this approach better.  I'll make the adjustments today and update this.  Thanks for the feedback!

When running Fluo's ITs against 2.0.0-alpha-1 there was a lot of stuff printed because of this log statement.  The classpath is what makes the log msg so long.  For each process mini starts, it logs which prints the classpath again.  So it prints alot and duplicates.

It appears that the code getting the tableConfig is looking in the JobConf for a key that must be missing.  Here is how the tableConfig is pulled from the job configuration: https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/1.9/core/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/core/client/mapreduce/lib/impl/InputConfigurator.java#L679

The key which should be something like: "AccumuloInputFormat.InputConfigurator.ScanOpts.table_configs" or "AccumuloInputFormat.ScanOpts.TableConfigs"

Although I am not sure this should be set internally or not.  This could be a bug elsewhere.  I will look into this further.

> I think the minimal information of what process is being started should be logged at info.

@deniskuzZ : Just a quick note, the `ACCUMULO-XXXX` version numbering scheme applies to JIRA, not GitHub issues. To reference another issue on GitHub, just do `#XXXX`

> I don't think this is useful information. The process may not even start. I think what may be more useful would be if mini logged when processed unexpectedly exited.

For a user who isn't 100% familiar with what Mini is *supposed* to be doing under the hood (casual users, users who aren't Accumulo developers, but application developers who use Accumulo), I think that the minimum information is very useful. I agree it would be even more useful to report unexpected exits... but log lines that establish that it *should* be running process X, Y, and Z, provide a base context in which a user is more easily able to understand error messages about unexpected exits of those processes.

I don't think log messages that repeatedly spam the same information every time a piece of software runs is a good way to document how that software works for new users.  Would be better to put this info in documentation.

Check to make sure AccumuloRowInputFormat.setInputTableName(JobConf, tableName) is called.  I suspect this is why the tableConfig is null.  That method we were looking at will fall back and call getDefaultInputTableConfig() which will just get the config using the tableName set in that static method.  Looking at our tests, it seems to do this for everything. @SebeiHiba Accumulo 2.x is built against Hadoop 3, and is intended to work against that version. It may be possible to run it against older versions of Hadoop, and doing so may require patching Accumulo or altering its classpath at runtime, but since it was not developed against Hadoop 3, the only way to know is to try. Personally, I would recommend upgrading Hadoop before using Accumulo 2.x instead of trying to force Accumulo 2.x to run on older Hadoop versions.

For what it's worth, Accumulo 1.9 is built to work against either Hadoop 2 or Hadoop 3, and should only require class path changes at runtime.

@keith-turner and @ctubbsii please take a look at these 3 commits as the next step in this cleanup process, building on #425 and I can close #720.  These changes have been dialed back to the following:

1. Copy back the MapReduce code from the new client-mapreduce module back into core.client to preserve backwards compatibility of core.
2. Rename the new client-mapreduce packages to avoid conflicting with the old ones
3. Remove the dependency for client-mapreduce from test pom since test is now using the old ones again.  This commit also had sorting and formatting cleanup for the new package names.

This will build on the work already done without breaking things.  Getting these changes will allow someone else to go through deprecating the old MapReduce code while simultaneously working on a new API.
